content.content:
Your LinkedIn summary is one of the first things someone will see when they click on your LinkedIn profile. Think of the summary like a public cover letter — it doesn’t need to include everything, but it should highlight your top skills and experience to draw people in.

One study found that job applicants in a wide range of industries were 71% more likely to get an interview if they had a comprehensive LinkedIn profile — and that includes a summary. (Source: ResumeGo)

items: Highlight your expertise, work experience, and personality. Give recruiters some insight into what it’s like to work with you.

Learn from job postings. If you don’t know where to start, look for keywords in job postings that interest you. What qualities are they looking for? If any of those keywords apply to you, add them to your summary.
Aim for 3 to 5 short paragraphs. This is the place to tell your career story, but keep it short. A recruiter should be able to skim your whole profile in about 30 seconds.
End with an invitation to connect. Let people know what opportunities you’re looking for.

content.content: The best examples to study are from people in your own industry. Here are some that contain strong keywords for their specific industries.

I’m a freelance multi-disciplinary graphic designer who’s delivered creative and engaging solutions across brand identity, packaging, and digital media.

In 2013, my online brand campaign for the Dorsey Children’s Hospital won a GDUSA award, one of the most prestigious honors in the graphic design industry.

My work has also been featured in Creatique Bloq, Compound Magazine, and on the Creative Review blog.

Skills: logo design, web design, branding and identity, typography, UI design, packaging, CSS, HTML, InDesign, Photoshop, Illustrator

If you have a project I can help with, please get in touch. (Source: The Muse)

I have more than 5 years of experience as a dedicated sales professional in the retail industry. 

I believe the key to sustainable profit and sales is to focus on the consumer, and that's why I've managed to increase the customer base and profit growth in each of my roles as a sales professional. 

Colleagues would describe me as a friendly competitor driven by results and hard work.
Jot down some responses to these prompts. Then weave together 3 to 5 short paragraphs that draw from these answers. Don’t forget to end your summary with an invitation for people to reach out to you.
